bibl.title: Letter from Robert Carter to James Bradley, July 22, 1728

div1.p: Robert Carter writes to London merchant James Bradley, July 22, 1728, to remind him of a bill of lading sent earlier and to enclose an invoice (not present) for goods.

div1.head: Letter from Robert Carter to James Bradley, July 22, 1728

opener.dateline:
Rappa[hannock, Lancaster County, Virginia]
July the 22d: 1728
Mr James Bradley

div1.p:
My last went by Trice and brought you a
bill of Lading for some Tobbo: The occasion of this is to Inclose an
Invoice for a small parcelll of goods in the shiping whereof I
desire you will follow the directions therein given I Shall be more
perticular by the Carter remain
div1.closer:
Sr
your most humble Servant
Sent to York
Copy per Carter

div1.head: NOTES
div1.note: Source copy consulted: Robert Carter Letter Book, 1727 April 13-1728 July 23, Carter Family Papers, Virginia Historical Society, Richmond.

Robert Carter generally used a return address of "Rappahannock" for the river on which he lived rather than "Corotoman," the name of his home, on his correspondence, especially to merchants abroad. The county and colony have been added for clarity to the heading on the draft.

[1] James Bradley was a London merchant with whom Carter dealt from at least 1723 until his death. As noted in his letter to Bradley of 1727 May 17, Bradley owned the Welcome, but little information about Bradley has been located.

[2] The 140 ton Welcome was owned by London merchant James Bradley to whom Carter would write about her on 1727 May 17. John Trice (Frice) was her captain, 1723-1728. (Survey Report 6801 summarizing Adm 68/195, 154r, found in the microfilms of the Virginia Colonial Records Project, Albert and Shirley Small Special Collections Library, University of Virginia.)
